expanded_description: Supply schedules and supply curves are complementary tools that represent the relationship between price and quantity supplied. A supply schedule is a table showing specific price-quantity pairs, while a supply curve is the graphical representation of that same relationship. Understanding how to construct, interpret, and use these tools is essential for analyzing producer behavior and market dynamics.

core_concept.principle: A supply schedule is a table listing quantities supplied at various prices, holding all other factors constant. A supply curve is the graphical representation of a supply schedule, plotting price on the vertical axis and quantity supplied on the horizontal axis. Both show the same information—the relationship between price and quantity supplied—in different formats. The supply curve slopes upward from left to right, reflecting the law of supply. Every point on the supply curve represents a specific price-quantity combination from the supply schedule. The supply curve makes the direct relationship between price and quantity supplied visually clear and enables analysis of producer behavior, market outcomes, and policy effects.
core_concept.explanation:
Supply schedules and curves are the fundamental tools for analyzing producer behavior. They translate the abstract law of supply into concrete, usable information.

Consider a simple example—weekly supply of apples by an individual producer: Supply Schedule: At \$1 per apple → 50 apples supplied per week, At \$2 per apple → 100 apples supplied per week, At \$3 per apple → 150 apples supplied per week, At \$4 per apple → 200 apples supplied per week, At \$5 per apple → 250 apples supplied per week. This table shows the supply schedule—specific price-quantity pairs showing how many apples this producer is willing to supply at each price.

The same information can be shown graphically as a supply curve: Vertical axis: Price (\$1, \$2, \$3, \$4, \$5), Horizontal axis: Quantity (50, 100, 150, 200, 250 apples/week), Plot points: (50, \$1), (100, \$2), (150, \$3), (200, \$4), (250, \$5), Connect points with smooth curve sloping upward.

The supply curve makes the direct relationship visible—as you move up the price axis (higher prices), you move right along the quantity axis (higher quantities). Both formats are useful: Supply schedules provide precise numerical information, useful for calculations. Supply curves provide visual representation, useful for seeing relationships and comparing scenarios.

We distinguish between: Individual supply (one producer's supply schedule/curve—shows one firm's production behavior), Market supply (sum of all individual supplies—shows total quantity supplied by all producers at each price). Market supply is simply the horizontal sum of individual supplies—at each price, add up quantities supplied by all producers.

Understanding supply schedules and curves enables: Predicting producer behavior (how will production change if price changes?), Measuring producer surplus (difference between willingness to accept and actual price), Finding market equilibrium (where supply intersects demand), Analyzing policy effects (how do subsidies affect quantity produced?). These tools transform the abstract law of supply into practical analytical power.

sections.introduction: A supply schedule organizes information about the price-quantity relationship in table format. Understanding how to create and interpret supply schedules is the first step toward supply analysis.

key_concept.definition: A supply schedule is a table showing the quantity of a good that producers are willing and able to sell at each of various prices during a specific time period, ceteris paribus. Format: typically two columns—one for price, one for quantity supplied. The schedule lists multiple price points and corresponding quantities, showing how quantity supplied varies with price. Time period specification is essential (per day, per week, per year) because supply is a flow concept—quantity per unit of time.
key_concept.context: Supply schedules can represent individual supply (one producer) or market supply (all producers). They provide the foundation for constructing supply curves and performing economic calculations. The schedule must hold all other factors constant (ceteris paribus) to isolate the pure price effect.

principles.principle: Supply Schedules Show Direct Price-Quantity Relationship
principles.statement: In a properly constructed supply schedule, as price increases, quantity supplied increases (moving down the schedule). As price decreases, quantity supplied decreases (moving up the schedule). This reflects the law of supply.
principles.application: When reading a supply schedule, verify that it shows direct relationship—higher prices correspond to higher quantities.
principles.example: Individual supply schedule for handmade crafts per month: Price | Quantity Supplied, \$5 | 10 crafts, \$10 | 25 crafts, \$15 | 45 crafts, \$20 | 70 crafts. Pattern: Price ↑ → Quantity ↑. Direct relationship confirmed. If schedule showed price ↑ → quantity ↓, something would be wrong (violates law of supply, or other factors changing).

principles.principle: Each Entry Shows Willingness and Ability to Sell
principles.statement: Quantity supplied at each price represents what producers are both willing (want to sell) and able (can produce) to sell. Supply requires both desire and production capability.
principles.application: Supply schedules reflect effective supply—backed by production capacity, not just wishful thinking.
principles.example: Manufacturer supply schedule: At \$100 price → 500 units supplied (500 units can be profitably produced). Many more units might be desired (wish to sell 10,000), but only 500 can be produced profitably at \$100. Quantity supplied = 500 (effective supply), not 10,000 (wishful supply). At \$200 price → 2,000 units supplied (more units become profitable to produce). Supply schedule reflects production constraints.

principles.principle: Supply Schedules Hold Other Factors Constant (Ceteris Paribus)
principles.statement: A single supply schedule assumes all non-price factors remain constant—input costs, technology, expectations, weather (agriculture), number of sellers, etc. If these factors change, the entire schedule shifts (covered later).
principles.application: When constructing or interpreting supply schedules, explicitly note that other factors are held constant. Changes in those factors require new schedules.
principles.example: Wheat supply schedule: At \$5 → 1,000 bushels, At \$7 → 1,500 bushels, At \$9 → 2,000 bushels. This schedule assumes: Input costs constant (if fertilizer prices rise, entire schedule shifts), Technology constant (if new farming equipment introduced, schedule shifts), Weather constant (if drought occurs, schedule shifts), Expectations constant (if future price expectations change, schedule shifts). Ceteris paribus condition essential for isolating price effect.

principles.statement: Supply is a flow variable—quantity per unit of time. Supply schedules must specify the time period (per day, per month, per year) for quantities to be meaningful.
principles.application: Always include time period when presenting supply schedules. Without it, quantities are ambiguous.
principles.example: Ambiguous: At \$10 → 100 units supplied. Unclear timeframe. Clear: At \$10 → 100 units supplied per week. Now meaningful. Same producer at same price: 100 units per week = 5,200 units per year. Different time periods, different quantities. Time period specification essential.

worked_examples.title: Creating a Supply Schedule from Data
worked_examples.problem: Farm data shows wheat supply in a region: At \$4/bushel, farmers supply 100,000 bushels/month. At \$5/bushel, farmers supply 120,000 bushels/month. At \$6/bushel, farmers supply 150,000 bushels/month. At \$7/bushel, farmers supply 180,000 bushels/month. At \$8/bushel, farmers supply 220,000 bushels/month. (a) Construct the supply schedule. (b) Verify it follows law of supply. (c) What assumptions are implicit?

step_by_step.explanation: Organize data into standard two-column format: Price (per bushel) | Quantity Supplied (bushels per month), \$4.00 | 100,000, \$5.00 | 120,000, \$6.00 | 150,000, \$7.00 | 180,000, \$8.00 | 220,000. This is the supply schedule—shows quantity supplied at each price. Time period specified: bushels per month. Prices in ascending order (convention for easy reading).

Check for direct relationship between price and quantity: \$4.00 → \$5.00: Price ↑ \$1.00 (25%), Quantity ↑ 20,000 (20%). ✓ \$5.00 → \$6.00: Price ↑ \$1.00 (20%), Quantity ↑ 30,000 (25%). ✓ \$6.00 → \$7.00: Price ↑ \$1.00 (16.7%), Quantity ↑ 30,000 (20%). ✓ \$7.00 → \$8.00: Price ↑ \$1.00 (14.3%), Quantity ↑ 40,000 (22.2%). ✓ Every price increase corresponds to quantity increase. Direct relationship confirmed. Schedule follows law of supply.

This schedule assumes all other supply factors constant: Input costs constant: If fertilizer, seed, labor costs change, supply changes. Technology constant: If new farming equipment introduced, supply changes. Weather constant: If rainfall patterns change, supply changes. Number of farmers constant: If farmers enter/exit market, supply changes. Expectations constant: If expecting future price changes, current supply changes. Prices of alternative crops constant: If corn or soybean prices change, wheat supply changes. These factors held constant (ceteris paribus) to isolate price effect on quantity supplied.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Supply schedule: \$4→100K, \$5→120K, \$6→150K, \$7→180K, \$8→220K bushels/month. (b) Yes, follows law of supply—every price increase corresponds to quantity increase (direct relationship). (c) Implicit assumptions: input costs, technology, weather, number of farmers, expectations, and alternative crop prices all held constant. Schedule shows pure price effect, ceteris paribus.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Supply schedules organize price-quantity data systematically. They must show direct relationship (law of supply), specify time period (flow variable), represent willingness and ability to sell (effective supply), and hold other factors constant (ceteris paribus). Proper construction requires identifying and maintaining these conditions.

sections.introduction: A supply curve is the graphical representation of a supply schedule. Understanding how to plot supply curves from schedules and interpret them is essential for visual economic analysis.

key_concept.definition: A supply curve is a graph showing the relationship between the price of a good (vertical axis) and the quantity supplied (horizontal axis). It plots the price-quantity pairs from the supply schedule as points on a coordinate plane, then connects them with a smooth curve. Convention: Price on vertical (y) axis, Quantity on horizontal (x) axis. The curve slopes upward from left to right, reflecting the law of supply—as price rises, quantity supplied rises. Each point on the curve represents a specific price-quantity combination where producers are willing and able to sell that quantity at that price.
key_concept.context: Despite being called a 'curve,' supply curves are often drawn as straight lines for simplicity. Whether curved or linear, they slope upward. The graphical representation makes the direct relationship visible and enables geometric analysis of producer surplus, market equilibrium, and policy effects.

principles.principle: Standard Axes: Price Vertical, Quantity Horizontal
principles.statement: By convention, supply curves always plot price on the vertical (y) axis and quantity on the horizontal (x) axis. This is standard across all economics—always use this orientation.
principles.application: When plotting supply curves, always put price vertical and quantity horizontal, regardless of which is the 'independent' variable conceptually.
principles.example: Plotting supply for apples: Vertical axis: Price (\$1, \$2, \$3, \$4, \$5). Horizontal axis: Quantity (0, 50, 100, 150, 200, 250 apples per week). Plot points from schedule, connect with upward-sloping line. Note: Technically, price is independent variable (we vary price to see quantity response), so mathematically it should be horizontal. But economics convention: Price always vertical. Follow convention for consistency with all economic analysis.

principles.statement: The supply curve slopes upward from lower left to upper right, reflecting the direct relationship between price and quantity supplied (law of supply). Higher prices correspond to points high on vertical axis and right on horizontal axis (high quantity). Lower prices correspond to points low on vertical axis and left on horizontal axis (low quantity).
principles.application: Always verify supply curves slope upward. Downward slope indicates error (or rare exception like backward-bending labor supply).
principles.example: Supply curve for bicycles: Point A: (50 bicycles, \$100) low on graph (low price, low quantity). Point B: (100 bicycles, \$200) middle of graph. Point C: (150 bicycles, \$300) higher on graph. Point D: (200 bicycles, \$400) high on graph (high price, high quantity). Connecting A→B→C→D creates upward-sloping curve. Visual representation of law of supply.

principles.principle: Every Point on the Curve Represents a Price-Quantity Pair
principles.statement: Each point on the supply curve shows the quantity producers supply at that specific price. Moving along the curve shows how quantity supplied changes as price changes, holding other factors constant.
principles.application: Can read quantity supplied at any price by finding corresponding point on curve.
principles.example: Supply curve for solar panels: At \$200 price: Find \$200 on vertical axis, move horizontally to supply curve, drop vertically to horizontal axis → read 10,000 panels supplied. At \$300 price: Same process → read 15,000 panels supplied. At \$400 price: Read 20,000 panels supplied. Each point on curve tells quantity supplied at that price.

principles.principle: Curve Can Be Linear or Curved, Still Called 'Supply Curve'
principles.statement: Supply curves can be straight lines (linear) or curved lines (nonlinear). Both are called 'supply curves' by convention. Linear supply curves have constant slope. Curved supply curves have changing slope (usually steepening as quantity increases due to rising marginal costs).
principles.application: Don't be confused by terminology—'supply curve' doesn't necessarily mean curved shape. It's the generic term for the graphical supply relationship.
principles.example: Linear supply: Straight line from (0, \$10) to (100, \$110). Slope constant everywhere: \$1 per unit. Simple to work with mathematically. Nonlinear supply: Curved line, gentle at low quantities, steep at high quantities. Slope changes: gentle portion \$0.50 per unit, steep portion \$2 per unit. More realistic for many goods (rising marginal costs). Both called 'supply curves.'

worked_examples.title: Plotting a Supply Curve from a Schedule
worked_examples.problem: Producer's supply schedule for artisanal bread per day: \$5 → 10 loaves, \$8 → 25 loaves, \$12 → 40 loaves, \$15 → 50 loaves, \$20 → 60 loaves. (a) Plot the supply curve. (b) What quantity is supplied at \$10? (c) At what price is quantity supplied equal to 30 loaves?

step_by_step.explanation: Set up axes: Vertical (y) axis: Price (\$0 to \$25 in \$5 increments). Horizontal (x) axis: Quantity (0 to 70 loaves in 10-loaf increments). Plot points from schedule: Point A: (10 loaves, \$5), Point B: (25 loaves, \$8), Point C: (40 loaves, \$12), Point D: (50 loaves, \$15), Point E: (60 loaves, \$20). Connect points with smooth curve sloping upward from lower left (A) to upper right (E). This is the supply curve—visual representation of the supply schedule.

Price \$10 is between plotted points B (\$8) and C (\$12). Interpolate between these points: At \$8 → 25 loaves. At \$12 → 40 loaves. At \$10 (50% of way from \$8 to \$12): Quantity ≈ 25 + 0.5(40-25) = 25 + 7.5 = 32.5 loaves. Approximately 32-33 loaves supplied at \$10 price. Graphically: Find \$10 on vertical axis, move horizontally right to supply curve, drop down to horizontal axis → read approximately 32.5 loaves.

step_by_step.step: Part (c): Find price where quantity supplied = 30 loaves
step_by_step.explanation: Quantity 30 is between plotted points B (25 loaves) and C (40 loaves). Interpolate: At 25 loaves → \$8. At 40 loaves → \$12. At 30 loaves (33% of way from 25 to 40): Price ≈ \$8 + 0.33(\$12-\$8) = \$8 + \$1.33 = \$9.33. At approximately \$9.33 price, quantity supplied equals 30 loaves. Graphically: Find 30 on horizontal axis, move vertically up to supply curve, move horizontally left to vertical axis → read \$9.33.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Supply curve: upward-sloping curve through points (10, \$5), (25, \$8), (40, \$12), (50, \$15), (60, \$20). (b) At \$10 price, quantity supplied ≈ 32.5 loaves (between 25 and 40). (c) At quantity supplied of 30 loaves, price ≈ \$9.33. Supply curve allows reading price-quantity relationships in both directions.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Supply curves are plotted with price on vertical axis, quantity on horizontal axis. Points from supply schedule are plotted and connected with upward-sloping curve. The curve allows reading quantities supplied at various prices (and vice versa), including interpolating between plotted points. Visual representation makes the direct price-quantity relationship clear and enables graphical analysis.

image.caption: Plotting supply curve: price on vertical axis, quantity on horizontal axis, connect points from supply schedule with upward-sloping curve

sections.introduction: Individual supply represents one producer's behavior, while market supply represents all producers combined. Understanding how to aggregate individual supplies into market supply is essential for analyzing markets.

key_concept.definition: Individual supply is the supply schedule or curve for a single producer, showing how much that firm wants to sell at various prices. Market supply is the sum of all individual supplies, showing total quantity supplied by all producers at each price. Market supply is found by horizontal summation—at each price, add up the quantities supplied by all producers. Market supply curve lies to the right of any individual supply curve because it represents more sellers.
key_concept.context: Most economic analysis focuses on market supply because markets involve many sellers. But market supply is simply the aggregation of individual supplies—understanding individual behavior is the foundation for understanding market outcomes.

principles.principle: Market Supply Is Horizontal Sum of Individual Supplies
principles.statement: To find market supply, take each price and sum the quantities supplied by all individual producers at that price. Repeat for all prices. This is called horizontal summation because you're adding quantities (horizontal axis) at each price level.
principles.application: Given individual supply schedules, sum quantities at each price to create market supply schedule.
principles.example: Two producers, lemonade supply: Producer A: At \$1 → 20 cups, At \$2 → 40 cups, At \$3 → 60 cups. Producer B: At \$1 → 30 cups, At \$2 → 50 cups, At \$3 → 70 cups. Market supply (A + B): At \$1 → 20+30 = 50 cups total, At \$2 → 40+50 = 90 cups total, At \$3 → 60+70 = 130 cups total. Market supply schedule shows combined production.

principles.principle: Market Supply Curve Lies to the Right of Individual Curves
principles.statement: Because market supply represents more producers, at any given price, market quantity supplied exceeds any individual's quantity supplied. Graphically, market supply curve is to the right of individual supply curves.
principles.application: Market supply is always greater than individual supply at every price level (assuming positive individual supplies).
principles.example: Wheat supply at \$4 per bushel: Farmer A supplies 1,000 bushels. Farmer B supplies 1,500 bushels. Farmer C supplies 2,000 bushels. Market supply: 1,000+1,500+2,000 = 4,500 bushels total at \$4. Graphically: Individual curves pass through (1,000, \$4), (1,500, \$4), (2,000, \$4). Market curve passes through (4,500, \$4)—to the right of all individual curves. More producers → greater total quantity.

principles.principle: Market Supply Inherits Law of Supply from Individuals
principles.statement: If all individual supply curves slope upward (law of supply), market supply curve must also slope upward. Direct relationship holds at aggregate level because it holds at individual level.
principles.application: Market supply follows law of supply because it's built from producers who follow law of supply.
principles.example: Each producer: Higher price → higher individual quantity supplied (law of supply). Market (sum of producers): Higher price → higher quantity for each producer → higher total quantity supplied. Market supply slopes upward because individual supplies slope upward.

principles.statement: As more producers enter the market, market supply increases at every price. The market supply curve shifts rightward when new firms enter.
principles.application: Market size affects total supply. Larger markets have greater supply at every price.
principles.example: Original market: 50 producers. At \$10 → each supplies 100 units → market supply 5,000 units. New entrants: 70 producers. At \$10 → each supplies 100 units → market supply 7,000 units. 40% more producers → 40% more market supply. Market supply curve shifted right.

worked_examples.title: Deriving Market Supply from Individual Supplies
worked_examples.problem: Three producers in a market for artisanal cheese per month. Producer A: \$15→100, \$20→150, \$25→200 pounds. Producer B: \$15→50, \$20→120, \$25→180 pounds. Producer C: \$15→200, \$20→250, \$25→300 pounds. (a) Derive market supply schedule. (b) Plot individual and market supply curves. (c) What happens to market supply if Producer D enters with same supply as Producer A?

step_by_step.explanation: Sum quantities at each price: At \$15: A(100) + B(50) + C(200) = 350 pounds total. At \$20: A(150) + B(120) + C(250) = 520 pounds total. At \$25: A(200) + B(180) + C(300) = 680 pounds total. Market supply schedule: Price | Market Quantity Supplied, \$15 | 350 pounds/month, \$20 | 520 pounds/month, \$25 | 680 pounds/month. This is horizontal summation—added quantities (horizontal) at each price.

Individual curves: Producer A: Plot (100, \$15), (150, \$20), (200, \$25). Connect with upward slope. Producer B: Plot (50, \$15), (120, \$20), (180, \$25). Connect with upward slope. Producer C: Plot (200, \$15), (250, \$20), (300, \$25). Connect with upward slope. Market curve: Plot (350, \$15), (520, \$20), (680, \$25). Connect with upward slope. Observation: At each price, market quantity (350, 520, 680) is sum of individual quantities. Market curve to the right of all individual curves. All curves slope upward (law of supply).

Producer D enters with same supply as A: \$15→100, \$20→150, \$25→200. New market supply (A+B+C+D): At \$15: 350 (old) + 100 (D) = 450 pounds. At \$20: 520 (old) + 150 (D) = 670 pounds. At \$25: 680 (old) + 200 (D) = 880 pounds. Effect: Market supply increased at every price. Market supply curve shifted rightward. More producers → greater market supply. New market supply schedule: \$15→450, \$20→670, \$25→880 pounds.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Market supply: \$15→350, \$20→520, \$25→680 pounds/month (horizontal sum of individual supplies). (b) Individual curves show individual production; market curve shows total production at each price, lying to the right of all individual curves. All slope upward. (c) Producer D entering increases market supply to \$15→450, \$20→670, \$25→880 pounds—market supply curve shifts right when more producers enter.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Market supply is horizontal summation of individual supplies—at each price, add all individual quantities supplied. Market supply curve lies to the right of individual curves (represents more producers). Market supply inherits upward slope from individuals (law of supply). Adding producers shifts market supply rightward, increasing quantity supplied at every price. Market analysis aggregates individual behaviors.

summary:
Supply schedules and supply curves are complementary tools representing the relationship between price and quantity supplied. A supply schedule is a table listing quantities supplied at various prices, organized with price in one column and corresponding quantity supplied in another. The schedule shows the direct relationship between price and quantity (law of supply) through numerical data, with higher prices corresponding to higher quantities and vice versa. Each entry represents quantity producers are both willing and able to sell (effective supply, not wishful thinking). The schedule must specify a time period (per day, per week, per year) because supply is a flow variable—quantity per unit of time. The ceteris paribus condition is essential—the schedule holds all non-price factors constant (input costs, technology, expectations, number of sellers) to isolate the pure price effect.

A supply curve is the graphical representation of the supply schedule, plotting price on the vertical axis and quantity supplied on the horizontal axis by convention (always use this orientation in economics). Points from the supply schedule are plotted as coordinates (quantity, price) and connected with a smooth curve. The supply curve slopes upward from left to right, reflecting the law of supply—as you move up the price axis (higher prices), you move right along the quantity axis (higher quantities supplied). Each point on the curve represents a specific price-quantity combination showing how much producers supply at that price. Despite being called a 'curve,' supply curves can be linear (straight lines with constant slope) or nonlinear (curved lines with changing slope)—both are called supply curves by convention. The curve allows reading quantities supplied at any price and prices at any quantity, including interpolating between plotted points.

Individual supply represents one producer's production behavior at various prices, showing a single firm's supply schedule or curve. Market supply represents all producers combined, showing total quantity supplied by everyone at each price. Market supply is derived through horizontal summation—at each price, add up the quantities supplied by all individual producers. The process: take a price, sum all individual quantities supplied at that price, repeat for all prices to create market supply schedule. Market supply curve lies to the right of any individual supply curve because it represents more producers selling at each price. Market supply inherits the law of supply from individuals—if individual curves slope upward, market curve must also slope upward. Adding more producers to the market increases market supply at every price, shifting the market supply curve rightward. Market size directly affects total supply—larger numbers of producers create greater market supply.

Supply schedules provide precise numerical information useful for calculations and detailed analysis. Supply curves provide visual representation useful for seeing relationships, comparing scenarios, and geometric analysis of producer surplus, equilibrium, and policy effects. Both formats show the same fundamental information—the price-quantity relationship—but serve different analytical purposes.

Understanding how to construct supply schedules from data, plot supply curves from schedules, interpret points on curves, aggregate individual supplies into market supply, and translate between numerical and graphical formats is essential for economic analysis. These tools transform the abstract law of supply into concrete, usable frameworks for analyzing producer behavior, predicting market responses to price changes, measuring welfare (producer surplus), finding equilibrium (where supply meets demand), and evaluating policy effects (subsidies, taxes, regulations). Mastery of supply schedules and curves is foundational to all further microeconomic analysis.
